>From: Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@...>
>
>Hi,
>          I can't quite get the details of your 4 approaches from these
>brief descriptions, can you post some pseudo-code.

I actually posted the real code to the group files section.

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/neat/files/compare.c

>Also networks was
>small, were you evaluating it over and over with different data?

Yes, I call it over and over again with random numbers for each of the 10 
inputs, for a configurable amount of time, but usually 5 minutes.  So, for 
example, the fastest one would have activated it almost 136 million times.

As you'll see from the code, I also dynamically calculate 
activations-per-second as I go so that I can do the activations in a tight 
loop, and only probe the clock once per second.  So the overhead for the 
timing mechanism is minimal.

I could have used a larger network, but the purpose of the experiment was to 
see what effect different ways of structuring the activation code might 
have.  And this network size was more than adequate to this task.
